profileText: A Delegate from Rhode Island; born at Marthas Vineyard, Mass., April 9, 1741; attended school in Newport, R.I., where his father had moved, and was graduated from Philadelphia College (now the University of Pennsylvania) at Philadelphia in 1762; studied law; was admitted to the bar about 1767 and commenced practice in Newport, R.I.; attorney general of Rhode Island 1771-1777; Member of the Continental Congress 1777-1779 and was one of the signers of the Articles of Confederation; delegate to the Rhode Island State Convention in 1789 for the adoption of the Federal Constitution; served as United States district judge for the district of Rhode Island 1790-1796; died in Newport, R.I., on August 30, 1796; interment in the Common Burial Ground.

creativeWork.freeFormCitationText: Lovejoy, David S. ``Henry Marchant and the Mistress of the World.'' William and Mary Quarterly 3d ser., 12 (July 1955): 375-98.

researchRecord.name: In the Autographs of the Signers of the Articles of Confederation,1769, 1 item.

recordLocation.name: Department of Literary and Historical Manuscripts

researchRecord.name: 1922, 1 page.
researchRecord.description: A letter from George Simpson Eddy to the Librarians of Brown University written on July 21, 1922. Subjects referred to include Henry Marchant.

researchRecord.name: 1771-1772, 202 pages.
researchRecord.description: An account by Henry Marchant of a voyage from Newport, Rhode Island, to London, with descriptions of Boston, Dover, London, Edinburgh, and other cities. There are also many references to Benjamin Franklin. A microfilm copy of the entire journal is in the Rhode Island Historical Society.

researchRecord.name: In the Harold Jantz Collection of Early Manuscripts, ca. 1477-1905, 13.5 linear feet.
researchRecord.description: Persons represented include Henry Marchant. A finding aid is available in the library.
